caption: Quantitative evaluation on SMITE-50 dataset. The results are presented for each category (Face, Horse, Car, Non-Text) having 10 reference image during training.
description: The table presents a quantitative evaluation of the SMITE model on the SMITE-50 dataset.  It shows the performance of three different methods: Baseline-1, GSAM2, and the proposed SMITE method, across four categories: Faces, Horses, Cars, and Non-Text. For each category and method, the table reports two metrics: F-measure and mIOU (mean Intersection over Union). The results are based on 10 reference images used during training for each category.

caption: Quantitative evaluation on SMITE-50 dataset. The results are presented for each category (Face, Horse, Car, Non-Text) having 10 reference image during training.
description: This table presents a quantitative evaluation of the SMITE model on the SMITE-50 dataset.  The results are broken down by four object categories: Faces, Horses, Cars, and Non-Text. For each category, the table shows the F-measure and mean Intersection over Union (mIOU) scores achieved by three different methods: Baseline-1 (a frame-by-frame SLiMe approach), GSAM2, and the proposed SMITE method.  The results indicate the performance of each method in segmenting objects within each category, providing a comparison of their performance in terms of segmentation accuracy and boundary precision.

caption: Quantitative evaluation on SMITE-50 dataset. The results are presented for each category (Face, Horse, Car, Non-Text) having 10 reference image during training.
description: The table presents a quantitative evaluation of the SMITE model on the SMITE-50 dataset.  It shows the performance of the SMITE model and two baseline methods (Baseline-1 and GSAM2) across four categories: Faces, Horses, Cars, and Non-Text. For each category and method, the F-measure and mean Intersection over Union (mIOU) are reported. The results are based on using 10 reference images during training.  The table highlights the superior performance of the SMITE model compared to the baseline methods in terms of both F-measure and mIOU across all four categories.

caption: Quantitative evaluation on SMITE-50 dataset. The results are presented for each category (Face, Horse, Car, Non-Text) having 10 reference image during training.
description: Table 1 presents a quantitative evaluation of the SMITE model on the SMITE-50 dataset.  The results are broken down by category (Faces, Horses, Cars, Non-Text), each trained with 10 reference images. For each category, the table shows the F-measure and mean Intersection over Union (mIOU) scores achieved by three different methods: Baseline-1 (a frame-by-frame application of SLiMe), GSAM2 (Grounded SAM2), and the proposed SMITE method.  The table allows for a comparison of the performance of the proposed SMITE method against existing baselines for video part segmentation across various object categories.

caption: Table 1: Quantitative evaluation on SMITE-50 dataset. The results are presented for each category (Face, Horse, Car, Non-Text) having 10 reference image during training.
description: Table 1 presents a quantitative evaluation of the SMITE model on the SMITE-50 dataset. The table displays the performance metrics for each category (Face, Horse, Car, Non-Text) using two metrics: F-measure and mIOU (mean Intersection over Union).  The results are broken down for three different methods: Baseline-1, GSAM2, and the proposed SMITE model. Each method is evaluated across the four categories, with the F-measure and mIOU values provided for each.  This allows for a direct comparison of the proposed model's performance against two existing baseline approaches across various object categories, highlighting its superior performance in terms of flexible granularity segmentation.
